Most recently, leaders of Iraq's biggest religious group disagreed about whether to keep Ibrahim al-Jafaari as the prime minister.
That disagreement pits rival religious parties, each with their own militias, against each other.
Today, we called Edward Wong, a reporter for the New York Times in Baghdad.
Mr. Wong, deep are the differences between various Shiite groups?
Well, the ones that you mentioned, the two major factions among the Shiites, their differences go back generations, back to the fathers of the current leaders of those two groups.
So the differences aren't reconcilable anytime soon.
And, even as recent as August, we saw those two groups unleashing their militias against each other.
And in the months since then, during the political process, each group has been doing all they can to foil the ambitions of the other group.
What are the major groups here?

On the one side, we've a group led by a cleric named Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, and that's caused the Supreme Council, and that's a group in exile in Iran for many years, whom Americans backed and brought back into Iraq.
And then, you've got another group led by Muqtada al-Sadr, the fairly young cleric who has led two rebellions against Americans.
And, of course, he has this powerful al-Madi army militia that the Americans would love to disband, but that they failed to do so for the last three years.
Are there serious differences in the way to take the countries between these two groups, or is it mainly a question of whose party's leaders are in control?
They do have serious differences about the political philosophy for the future of the country.
For example, the Supreme Council would like to see their country partitioned up into loose federal states, in which each region of the country has lots of autonomy.
They see the southern Shiite region of the country as one of these states, and it's got the vast majority of the oil resources there.
So, I think they see the Shiites as benefiting if the country were to break up into these states.
On the other hand, Muqtada al-Sadr wants a strong unified central government, partly because of the religious belief of the Sadr movement.
They really believe that a strong central government is in keeping with Islamist beliefs.
They believe in the prophecy of a mythical Imam that will come forward and unite all the countries of the world into Islamic faith.
Is there any danger the differences between these two armed groups could lead to a civil war just as easily as differences between Shias and Sunnis could?
Well, a lot of analysts do say that.

If a civil war were to emerge here Iraq, or full scale civil war, then intra-Shiite civil war would be just as likely as the Shiite versus Sunni civil war, that not only would Sunnis and Shiites be fighting each other, but factions within the Shiite community would be fighting each other.

At the same time, Muqtada al-Sadr has tried to work within the political system many times in the last year, so he might tell his militia to calm down and try to work within politics to resolve the matter.
